title: Miller column: Positive stories from the world of soccer
text:
Miller column: Positive stories from the world of soccer Brian Miller, Democrat staff writer 12:24 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Soccer goals are just one of the many expenses in fielding a team. Goals can cost $2,500 per pair, a cost too expensive for some schools to bear. (Photo: Michael Chow/Arizona Republic) Story Highlights Leon senior Jordan Ray gave up a roster spot on the soccer team to allow another senior to have it East Gadsden's boys soccer team is fundraising for rival West Gadsden so the Panthers can have goals 2 CONNECT 7 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
In a day and age where sports can seem so cutthroat and me-centric, here’s a bit of positivity to encourage you. 
And, hey, it comes from the world of soccer, which has been chastised plenty of times before for fan riots, ref attack and hair-grabbing players. 
The first story comes from Leon High’s girls soccer tryouts. One final spot was available to play for last year’s district champs and it went to senior Jordan Ray, who is also finishing up her swim season. 
“Good athlete, great attitude, the works,” said seventh-year Leon coach Tony Kidd. “She earned a spot by continuing to improve throughout the tryouts and catching everyone's attention.” Buy Photo 
Leon coach Tony Kidd was the 2014 All-Big Bend Coach of the Year last year. He’s alongside graduated Florida High player Anna Menendez, the All-Big Bend Player of the Year. (Photo: Joe Rondone/Democrat) 
Ray and another first-year player, a fellow senior, were given a chance under the lights of the stadium to prove themselves. Ray stood out the most and the coaches took notice. She got the last spot. 
As Kidd bagged up equipment, everyone else gone, Ray approached the coaches. She offered her roster spot to the senior let go because she already had a primary sport, but the other girl’s dream was to play soccer for Leon. 
Kidd had Ray tell her classmate she was on the team. As a show of support for Ray, the soccer team swarmed Leon’s swim meet against Lincoln last week. 
“You don't often see teenage kids perform such a selfless act,” Kidd said, “and this one will not be forgotten.” Buy Photo 
Leon’s Lily Henkel (20) and Lincoln’s Catherine Pratt (5) race after the ball during a 2014 game. (Photo: Democrat files) 
East Gadsden lends a hand 
After four years away from East Gadsden, Doug Stephens has returned to coach boys soccer in addition to his normal refereeing, teaching and pastoral duties. He’s also parenting seven children, two which he adopted. 
On the field, the Jaguars have a talented team according to Stephens, but he wants them to grasp a different concept than just winning. 
“East and West Gadsden are bitter rivals,” Stephens said. “I happened to hear that they were needing soccer goals, but did not have the money.” 
Soccer goals cost approximately $2,500 a pair, not exactly an easy cost for a school in one of the lowest financial districts in the state. 
So Stephens has his Jaguars helping raise the money for the Panthers through and alumni game this coming Saturday at 2:30 p.m. and 4 at Mt. Pleasant Field. The players and their families are also kicking in to help make up for the lack of business donors in Gadsden County. 
“I wanted my boys to have a bigger perspective than just rivalry,” Stephens said. “I wanted them to understand about what it is to give and help.” 
Soccer goals can cost $2,500 per pair, not an easy cost for an athletics department to absorb. East Gadsden is fundraising for rival West Gadsden so it can have goals.
